docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Disputes between companies and the families of the World Trade Center victims over health care coverage (front page, Dec. 26) reflect more than corporate penuriousness. They reflect America's failure to adopt a national health care system that covers all Americans, one that is affordable and financed fairly, based on ability to pay. The more than 40 million uninsured Americans can surely empathize with the victims' families because they, too, need health care coverage. It's time for our government to face this issue, not to be put off by the lobbying and campaign contributions of the insurance companies and others in the health care industry who insist that coverage exists to assure profits for companies rather than care for consumers. RHODA H. KARPATKIN New York, Dec. 26, 2001

docs.lead_paragraph: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sued the Allstate Insurance Company late yesterday after 15 months of trying to settle accusations that the insurer had discriminated against its agents. The suit, filed in United States District Court in Philadelphia without a formal announcement, centers on a decision by Allstate to convert its 15,200-member sales force from regular employees with pensions and health care benefits to independent contractors. To continue as contractors, the agents were required to sign a waiver, or release, that they would not sue Allstate. By last June, all but 6,400 of the agents had become contractors. The remaining agents, 90 percent of whom were older than 40, were then dismissed and given the choice of rejoining as contractors or leaving the company.

docs.lead_paragraph: Soon after Sept. 11, Marsh & McLennan Companies announced that it would provide the families of 295 employees killed in the World Trade Center attack with a year of full health insurance benefits. Senior executives considered the offer generous, yet quickly found themselves faced with an unexpected groundswell of anger. In letters and telephone calls, family members argued that a company with $10 billion in annual revenues -- the world's largest insurance brokerage, no less -- could surely do more to ease their worries about obtaining long-term health insurance.

docs.section_name: Front Page; Health; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Fifteen weeks have passed since terrorists took down the twin towers. Holidays have come and gone, none more poignant than this first Christmas in a changed world, a changed city, where no amount of tinsel can replace the sparkle of nearly 3,000 lost lives. But hesitantly, reluctantly, inevitably people are inching toward more normal lives, groping for wisdom and perspective. HOW TO PROVIDE -- Peace will come slowly, if at all, to the widows and widowers of 9/11 and to their employers, grappling with questions of corporate responsibility that are not answered in business-school text books. Take Marsh & McLennan, which lost 295 of 1,900 employees working in the World Trade Center. Like Cantor Fitzgerald before it, Marsh is now the focus of angry survivors. The fury engendered by its evolving compensation plans -- how long will families get health insurance coverage and who will pay for it? -- suggests that there are no easy or right answers when it comes to meeting expectations of the bereaved while remaining mindful of long-term financial consequences.

docs.lead_paragraph: Marsh & McLennan Revises Health Benefits for Families Soon after Sept. 11, Marsh & McLennan announced that it would provide the families of 295 employees killed in the attack with a year of full health insurance benefits. Senior executives considered the offer generous, but family members argued that a company with $10 billion in annual revenues could surely do more. Marsh & McLennan has decided to extend health coverage to the families for three years. But it will pay for the coverage not from corporate accounts, but from the MMC Victims Relief Fund, a charity established by the company to help provide for the families of the 295 employees who died. docs.lead_paragraph: Friendships born around a water cooler tend to fade when people leave their jobs and no longer have office gossip to share. While the Internet has not exactly overturned that pattern, it has created a forum for hundreds of e-mail lists and Web sites that enable former colleagues to keep in touch, plan reunions and share job leads. The trend is more prevalent among former employees of technology companies, but as tools have emerged that make setting up Web sites and chat rooms easier, the concept has spread to mainstream industries. Through Yahoo Groups, a service that lets anyone set up an e-mail list on a given theme, more than 150 groups of former employees -- including former workers at a DaimlerChrysler plant in Argentina and ex-teammates from the Toronto Blue Jays -- have started such information exchanges.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Anthrax Investigation CHASING A MYSTERY -- From the first case of skin anthrax misdiagnosed in late September to the death of a Connecticut woman the day before Thanksgiving and to efforts beyond, the story of an unprecedented epidemiological investigation. It is an account of misunderstood clues, dead-end leads and important lessons won doggedly and painfully by doctors, researchers and investigators. A1 Mission in Afghanistan RECLAIMING THE KILLING FIELD -- Just traces of the horrors that took place at Kandahar Sport Stadium can be seen now as children again use the field for soccer games. But a bullet-pierced goalpost and patches of soil darkened by blood still attest to the summary executions and enforced amputations that happened there by order of the Taliban while residents gathered to watch.
